Message.Title: AAPL + NVDA = new iMac. Goes on sale today
Message.Msg: Latest Apple iMac 21.5-inch Model will go on sale from this Friday for $1299 JASON SAMS NOVEMBER 28, 2012 0 COMMENTS Apple has announced today that it will roll out its redesigned iMac Desktop computers on Friday for sale. The latest iMac Desktop from apple will be available for sale from November 30th. Meanwhile the 21.5 inch iMac with a price tag of $1299 will be available with the Apple’s Online and Retail outlets from Friday. It will also be available at select and authorized reseller stores also. The bigger version, the 27 inch iMac with a price tag of $1799 will be available for pre-orders from Friday. However it will be shipped in December. The all in one iMac was introduced by Apple way back on October 23rd. However it announced that the devices will not be shipped immediately and no reason was given for this. Later Tim Cook, CEO announced that there has been some issues and the iMac will be delayed for quite some time.

Topic.Title: When are we gonna see the 1st Snapdragon S4 powered Win 8 tablet?

Message.Msg: this is such a stupid argument - what is the real value in having a quad-core? There is no tangible benefit to many applications from having quad-core. This is marketing hype. You can see benchmarks after benchmarks where Tegra 3 has its behind handed to it in both CPU and GPU results. The reason is that all benchmarks utilize single core. Things that matter are cpu speed, memory speed, architectural design. Tegra 3 was based on older ARM architecture, utilizes slower internal memory and architecture. I have said in past, Tegra 4 will be an improvement but its just a matter of time before its again bested by the next release from QCOM etc. There is no real innovation in packing 3rd party ARM core. To that point, Mediatek will be putting out Octa Core (yes 8 core) and Mediatek has many other assets that they have developed in wireless that they can integrate. So good luck in trying to differentiate with core-count.

Topic.Title: When are we gonna see the 1st Snapdragon S4 powered Win 8 tablet?

Message.Msg: "There is no real innovation in packing 3rd party ARM core." Agree "So good luck in trying to differentiate with core-count." NVidia will differentiate with Project Denver CPU cores...

Topic.Title: When are we gonna see the 1st Snapdragon S4 powered Win 8 tablet?

Message.Msg: "will"... see that is the problem. Intel "will" dominate mobility with "Atom". AMD "will" compete with Intel after ATI merger. If you know Nvidia, you know the history of Project Denver (its a 8+ year old project) and its many iterations. It was a classic case of over-promise and under-deliver. Will it come out and be useful in some form of computing - maybe. "Will" it take the computing/mobility world by storm - certainly not.

Message.Title: NVDA vs ARMH
Message.Msg: The company collects a small royalty for every ARM-compatible chip that is shipped, and despite 2.2B ARM-compatible products shipped in Q2 (but license revenue recognized in Q3), ARM only saw $107M in profits before tax. To make it perfectly clear, despite having nearly 100% of the smartphone and tablet market, as well as nearly the entirety of the microcontroller and embedded space, ARM fails to generate net income that comes out to even a fraction of that of its licensees and peers in the semiconductor industry. The company's initial success in the mobile computing markets has been primarily due to the firm's long-standing focus on the low power/embedded space, which allowed its products to evolve, due primarily to process technology advancements, to become fast enough to enable smartphones and tablets. The low power, low ASP application processor segment was largely overlooked by larger competitors early on, which gave ARM and its licensees the spotlight in the mobile processor world. However, going forward, it is clear that the actual ARM core designs will become less important, and that ARM's primary role in the mobile world will be as an instruction set licensee, given that there is now a substantial software base for the firm's instruction set in place. No other company could reasonably hope to compete in designing its own instruction set (other than Intel and its already established X86 ISA) since the software support and toolset -- usually the product of many years of development -- would be an almost intractable barrier to overcome. In short, ARM's business model will generate consistent, but low amounts of revenue and net income compared to its peers, which means that it is very unlikely that it will ever grow the top and bottom lines enough to warrant its valuation. However, the stock has seen an extraordinary run post-earnings and even more recently over the last couple of days. The earnings report was nothing to write home about -- it beat analyst revenue forecasts by $2M (for a total quarterly sales figure of $227M) , and as a result, the company has gained over $4B in market capitalization.
